sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Blepharitis - Fungal infection of eye: 1 drop in affected eye(s) 4 to 6 times/day
  • Fungal conjunctivitis: 1 drop in affected eye(s) 4 to 6 times/day
  • Fungal keratitis, Caused by susceptible organisms including Fusarium solani: 1 drop in affected eye(s) every 1 to 2 hr for 3 to 4 days; then 1 drop 6 to 8 times daily; continue for 14 to 21 days or until resolution of active fungal keratitis

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: geriatric: no differences in safety and efficacy noted

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Blepharitis - Fungal infection of eye
  • Fungal conjunctivitis
  • Fungal keratitis, Caused by susceptible organisms including Fusarium solani
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Candidal vulvovaginitis
  • Oral candidiasis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to natamycin or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono: failure of improvement of keratitis after 7 to 10 days of therapy; evaluate for microorganisms not susceptible to natamycin

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ophthalmic: Natamycin probably exerts its antifungal effects by binding to sterols in the fungal cell membrane to produce a change in membrane permeability that allows loss of essential cellular constituents. Following topical application, natamycin is retained in the conjunctival fornices and attains effective concentrations within the corneal stroma. Significant drug concentration is usually not attained in the intraocular fluid.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient on proper ophthalmic instillation technique.
  • Tell patient to not wear contact lenses until infection resolves or until approved by healthcare professional.
